channel.title: do
channel.description: do is a podcast about Ruby, Rubyists and their culture. We hope to grow to be a regular (at this stage, two-weekly) show, with a rotating panel of up to 10 people.

item.title: Show 3: Capistrano with Lee Hambley
item.description:
An interview with Lee Hambley (github, twitter) about Capistrano, it’s current status and maintainership.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe

Interview questions:

  • What got you interested in Capistrano in the first place?
  • How did you become the maintainer of Capistrano?
  • Can you summarise your recent public statement?
  • What did it feel like to have to admit that it was all too much?
  • What was the response to your public statement?
  • How are you feeling about it today?
  • Will you consider maintaining large open source projects in future?
  • How has maintaining a large open source project impacted your usage of other large projects?
  • What advice do you have to reduce the likelihood of other project maintainers reaching the same point of burnout?
  • What things can contributors or users of open source do to help maintainers?

Panelists:

  • Amanda Wagener
  • Henry Maddocks
  • James Harton
  • Philip Arndt
  • Tim Carey-Smith

item.title: Show 2: A globally distributed team
item.description:
An interview with Andrew Hooker (github, twitter) and Ryan Bigg (github, twitter) of Spree Commerce, where we discuss the implications of working inside of a globally distributed team, and on a set of products which comprise a large open source component.

MP3 Download, RSS Subscribe

Topics covered:

  • How Spree is coordinated and features are decided
  • Sprint planning across time zones
  • GitHub workflow
  • Spree team structure
  • How teams work across great distances

Panelists:

  • Amanda Wagener
  • Henry Maddocks
  • James Harton
  • Philip Arndt
  • Tim Carey-Smith

item.title: Show 1: Intro to "do"
item.description:
Who are these people? Why should I listen to them? Can they diverge onto massive tangents for many minutes at a time? Download MP3.

To find out the answer to all these questions and more, listen to our first ever show. Available for your downloading pleasure here or you can subscribe to our RSS feed in your favourite podcatcher.

item.title: do: A podcast about Ruby and Rubyists
item.description:
“do” is a podcast about Ruby, Rubyists and their culture. We hope to grow to be a regular (at this stage, two-weekly) show, with a rotating panel of up to 10 people.

Get involved.

The show schedule is managed in our GitHub issues, ideas for future shows can also be raised as issues for discussion, and may wind up being assigned to the schedule (issue milestones) for future recording.

Here’s how you can get involved:

  • If you’d like to be on a panel, add yourself to the panel list of an upcoming show. no more than 5 panelists, plus guest per show please!

  • If you’d like to be present at the recording of one of our episodes? Just follow us on Google+ and we’ll post events for our upcoming hangouts-on-air.

  • Make show or interview suggestions by raising or commenting on our GitHub issues.

channel.itunes:keywords: ruby, rails, programmer, programming, technology, learn, code, coder, tools, computers
